inputs.description: adds 'n' planes of zero at the Inferior edge
inputs.name: __I__

inputs.description: adds 'n' planes of zero at the Superior edge
inputs.name: __S__

inputs.description: adds 'n' planes of zero at the Anterior edge
inputs.name: __A__

inputs.description: adds 'n' planes of zero at the Posterior edge
inputs.name: __P__

inputs.description: adds 'n' planes of zero at the Left edge
inputs.name: __L__

inputs.description: adds 'n' planes of zero at the Right edge
inputs.name: __R__

inputs.description: adds 'n' planes of zeros on EACH of the dataset z-axis (slice-direction) faces
inputs.name: __Z__

inputs.description: These options specify that planes should be added/cut
inputs.name: __RL__

inputs.description: symmetrically to make the resulting volume have
inputs.name: __AP__

inputs.description: 'a', 'b', and 'c' slices in the respective directions.
inputs.name: __IS__

inputs.description: pad counts 'n' are in mm instead of slices: * each 'n' is an integer * at least 'n' mm of slices will be added/removed: n =  3 and slice thickness = 2.5 mm ==> 2 slices added n = -6 and slice thickness = 2.5 mm ==> 3 slices removed
inputs.name: __MM__

inputs.description: match the volume described in dataset 'mset': * mset must have the same orientation and grid spacing as dataset to be padded * the goal of -master is to make the output dataset from 3dZeropad match the spatial 'extents' of mset (cf. 3dinfo output) as much as possible, by adding/subtracting slices as needed. * you can't use -I,-S,..., or -mm with -master
inputs.name: __MASTER__

inputs.description: write result into dataset with prefix 'ppp' [default = 'zeropad']  Nota Bene: * You can use negative values of n to cut planes off the edges of a dataset.  At least one plane must be added/removed or the program won't do anything. * Anat parent and Talairach markers are NOT preserved in the new dataset. * If the old dataset has z-slice-dependent time offsets, and if new (zero filled) z-planes are added, the time offsets of the new slices will be set to zero. * You can use program '3dinfo' to find out how many planes a dataset has in each direction. * Program works for byte-, short-, float-, and complex-valued datasets. * You can use a sub-brick selector on the input dataset.  Author: RWCox - July 2000  ++ Compile date = May 25 2018 {AFNI_18.1.18:macosx_10.7_Intel_64}
inputs.name: __PREFIX__
